text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with lamb and rice stuffed grape
leaves that's right i'm going to show
you how to make what most people refer
to as dolmas well actually I'm going to
show you how I make them at least since
I'm not exactly sure how authentic these
are I mean it's not like I've ever had a
dolma tician certified their accuracy
but nevertheless I really do enjoy how
these come out and think you will as
well and by the way we will be doing the
less typical version that contains meat
and rice usually it's just rice but I
really do love the me filled versions so
let's go ahead and get started with the
stuffing so we're going to start with
some ground lamb to which we're going to
add some long grain rice which I have
not rinsed I want all the starch raus
going to need a nice glug of olive oil
and then we're going to throw in some
currants for a little sweetness as well
as some pine nuts but not for nuttiness
for richness I really don't consider the
flavor of pine nuts that nutty and then
of course like most stuff means we have
to season this aggressively so we're
going to need some salt of course and
some freshly ground black pepper we also
want to do a little bit of cumin as well
as a touch of cinnamon not too much but
a little touch is very nice here and
then a little bit of herb we'll do a
pinch of dry oregano as well as a good
amount of freshly chopped a mint which
of course pairs beautifully with lamb
otherwise how would you explain all the
mint jelly beans sold I mean no one's
putting that on toast right and then
last but not least to bind this we're
going to do one whole egg and we'll take
a fork and mix this thoroughly and
believe it or not that's it for the
stuffing very simple very
straightforward and extremely flavorful
and then once that's mixed we can just
pop it in the fridge until our grape
leaves are prepped which is the next
step and I'm going to use the ones that
come in the jar and they do come packed
in like a salty brine which you can just
go ahead and pour off so let's transfer
some of these to the cutting board so
you can take a look and no I'm not
finally doing that collab with Snoop
Dogg this is just a whole bunch of grape
leaves all rolled up into a let's say
cigar like object and by far the hardest
part of this whole operation is
unrolling these and separating the
leaves without tearing them to pieces so
start off carefully just slowly unroll
it until you see what you're dealing
with and eventually after a few
frustrating seconds they will start to
come apart and you can somehow someway
separate those leaves but very important
you can't start stuffing as soon as you
separate we have to rinse that brine off
the leaf so as I'm doing this I just
like to transfer those into a large bowl
of cold water and I might leave those in
for about 10 or 50 minutes to kind of
leach out a little bit of that brine
Younis and I know some recipes call for
blanching first I find that completely
unnecessary but bottom line before you
start stuffing you'll have to separate
and rinse off your leaves but once we do
we're ready to roll
literally so let's go ahead and place
one leaf flat down on a cutting board
and you'll notice they are ribbed but
not for anyone's pleasure that's simply
to tell us which side should be up so we
want the non rib side down those ribs
facing up and it should be pretty
obvious but if it's not simply put
whatever the smoothest side facing down
and then once we have our leaf properly
positioned we will place down a rounded
tablespoon of our lamb and rice filling
pretty much right in the center near the
bottom of the leaf and then what follows
is how I like to roll these up so I take
the two pieces of leaf at the bottom and
fold those over like this and then we'll
carefully fold over each side kind of
keeping everything as symmetrical as we
can and once those sides are folded over
we just sort of tuck and roll with that
last piece of leaf towards the front and
it should roll up into something looks
like that and we do want to roll these
sort of but not too tight okay they got
to be tight enough to stay together but
if you roll them overly tight they will
break open as that rice expands as it
cooks and this is a little bit
time-consuming but it goes way way
faster if you put like six or eight
leaves down on a cutting board at the
same time and then stuff and roll them
one after the other you should get a
little bit of a rhythm down and by the
way one of those jars is going to have
more grape leaves than you need so of
course you're going to use the biggest
and best leaves but don't throw away the
ugly and or torn ones because we're
going to use those as you'll see so I
continued rolling until my filling was
gone and for the amounts I'm using you
should get about thirty two of these or
so and then once all our Domus have been
rolled we can transfer those into our
pots but first we have to drizzle some
olive oil on the bottom and then cover
it with some of our reserved excess
grape leaves all right we want to
insulate our rolled and stuffed grape
leaves from the bottom and then once I
set we're going to go ahead and place
these in starting on the outside and
working towards the middle and very
important that donal should be just
barely touching but not smushed together
if they're too tight they're just not
going to cook properly and on the other
hand if they're too loose they
unravel it for me one batch will fill
the bottom of my pot perfectly but if
you do have some gaps no problem just
wad up some grape leaves and fill those
spaces and by the way you can do 2 or 3
layers of these and the recipe will work
just about the same and then once those
have been placed in properly let's bring
our pot over the stove and we will add
the last couple ingredients the first of
which would be some fresh lemon juice
we'll just squeeze that over and now
we're also going to give it one last
shot of olive oil just a little drizzle
over the top and then we're going to
need to pour our liquid in here Bob
before we do incredibly important we
need something to keep these Domas in
place while they cook and I'm going to
do that with a couple plates so I'm
going to put a smaller one in the center
and then a bigger one over the top and
besides pressing everything down with a
little bit of weight it's also going to
hold everything perfectly in place so
these don't unwrap as they cook at that
point we can pour in our liquid I'm
using chicken broth and once that's
poured in what we want to do is kind of
tilt the pot to make sure we don't have
any big air pockets underneath so kind
of tilted this way in that at that point
we can turn on our heat to medium high
and wait for bubbles and we're
definitely not talking about waiting for
a rolling boil we're just waiting for
our liquid to heat through and start to
simmer and as soon as we see that happen
here's the plan we're going to reduce
our heat to low we're going to cover
this and we're going to cook it for
about 45 minutes to an hour or until our
rice is perfectly tender what I like to
do is let it go for about 35 minutes or
so at which point I like to remove my
plates and kind of give them a test
they're usually not done by this point
but they're done enough to keep their
shape so at this point I'm going to give
them a little test with the fork as I
push it in I could feel that rice needs
a little more and also they didn't look
quite plumped up of course that didn't
stop me from eating one anyway because I
was starving but they weren't quite done
so I decided to give these about another
10 minutes or so without the plates the
plates serve their purpose so I just
covered those up cooked them like I said
for another 10 minutes or so until like
I said the rice was perfectly tender and
you can see they do look a little
plumper and once we've determined our
Domas are perfectly cooked and our rice
is tender we are ready to serve and
here's the good news these are great
served hot warm room temperature and
cold so I decided to serve them just
barely warm
is an appetizer so I'm gonna go ahead
and line those up on a platter and
garnish with a little bit of lemon zest
that's of course to distract people from
all the holes I may test them with a

had these served with a yogurt sauce
which is really good so you can do that
if you wanted you are the John Cleese of
your stuffed grape leaves and I'm
talking about the brilliant comedian
John Cleese not the character he played

one of the best shows ever but I'm just
going to do a little bit of fresh lemon
as well as one last drizzle of olive oil
and those lamb and rice stuffed grape
leaves are done just gorgeous to look at
delicious to eat and completely
addictive in fact while I was eating
these I was like why did you just make
32 I mean those are going to be gone in
let's see half minute divided in 16
minutes so that was the only drawback I
didn't make enough and like I said these
are typically made without the lamb just
with the rice and other spices but I
really do love the lamb in these
especially with that little sweetness
from the currants in the mint and the
cinnamon just a beautiful pairing with
the tartness from the lemon and that
kind of unique brightness of the grape
leaf it's just a fantastic thing to eat
so you've seen them on television you've
